If it is for comedy, there are hardly any comic situations - there are some strange situations and dialogs, some of them are amusing, but most of them are too undramatic and uneventful to be funny or at least absurd, and too unbelievable and illogical for being credible. All other features of this movie are just fine, but nothing to be impressed of.So again, what is the hype about? One possible reason could be that this sentimental love story appears somewhat dry and more intellectual than an average Hollywood production, so it is easier to commit to it ... but I don't see any other merit.

reviews.review_title: A great, unique story of youthful imagination...
reviews.content: Rushmore is undeniably one of the paramount achievements in modern film. It takes a somewhat trite  `coming of age' story to the next level by incorporating a dry and darkly comic edge, exposing the melancholy behind youthful innocence and hopeless romanticism. This is accomplished primarily through the surreal maturity found in its young characters, but also with the tenderly problematic older ones. Overall, Rushmore dispenses a gloomy charm, as the events of the film constantly teeter over failure, yet remain focused on fanciful dreams of success. The result is the ability of the audience to overlook disappointment and cherish the love of creation: to love the actual process of achievement, no matter how impossible or unattainable the ends may seem. In essence, Rushmore illustrates a new love for life, questioning whether one can ignore consequences in spite of the trivial pursuit of fun and invention. 10/10

I love this film, not only for the performances by Bill Murray, Jason Schwartzman, Olivia Williams and others, but also for the detail that went into. If you don't like this film, you obviously have no imaginations whatsoever.

I first seen Rushmore on Encore one night, and I knew that is was something special, when I could relate to all the characters like that. I watch this movie almost every day, and every time I watch it I appreciate it a little more. The film has Jason Schwartzman( in a great performance) as Max Fischer, a 15-year old at Rushmore, a local private school. Although Max is in about every club there is at school( and he creates many other ones), he is a lousy student, who is about to get expelled because of his poor grades. He actually only got into Rushmore on a scholarship for writing a play about Watergate at a young age. Max meets local steel tycoon Herman Blume( Bill Murray, giving his best performance to date; he should have been nominated for an Oscar), and this leads to Max giving Mr. Blume an idea about building an aquarium to please a 1'st grade teacher at Rushmore, Rosemary Cross( Olivia Williams), for whom Max has fell in love with. Then problems happen as Mr. Blume also falls in love with her, leading to lots of hilarious moments. Rushmore has three great assets that make it one of my favorite movies: 1. Acting- All of the performance here are fantastic. Schwartzman as Max gives a high energy performance that is so perfect here; Murray gives a touching performance as a man who hates his life, while Williams gives a good performance as Miss Cross, while Seymour Cassel ( playing Max's father) and Sara Tanaka( playing Max's love interest) also give good supporting performances. 2. Script- The script is so great that it's just incredible. The dialogue involving handjobs is hilarious, but amazingly not over-the-top. 3. Music- The music is so perfect that one of my top priorities right now is to buy the soundtrack, if it's avialable. It's so full of perfectly coordinated songs, that even if the acting and script were terrible, the movie would still be good. I think that one of the problems in Hollywood is that there isn't enough movies like Rushmore. Rushmore is a brilliant film, and it's a film actually about people for once.

This contains descriptions of scenes. It might "spoil" the movie a bit.A few years ago, this and the Big Lebowski were my favorite films ever, and I'd seen quite a few. Rushmore contains some of the coolest moments captured on film including the scene where a miserable Mr. Blume does a canonball from the highdive at his pool in his Budweiser trunks and the shot where Max exits the elevator after putting bees into Mr. Blume's hotel room and, in slow-mo, sticks his gum against the wall. If you don't this movie, you're not cool. Max is my kind of guy.

If I wrote this review after the first time I saw it, I would have called it boring and mediocre and I would've said that I didn't know why all the critics loved it. Now when I write this, I must tell you I love this movie! If you don't like it first, I can see why, but watch it a few more times, if you have the chance, and you will discover what a funny and beautiful movie it is. The Royal Tenenbaums is better, but Rushmore is still an amazing movie with a great sound track. Highly recommended.

I love it when I don't know what is going to happen, even within the context of a sort of romantic comedy. Rushmore is like watching Monthy Python's High School Comedy 2000. The great thing about it, is that nobody plays for laughs. Most of the scenes aren't even funny in itself, it's the context and the justapositioning that's makes it funny as hell.

reviews.review_title: One of the Top 10 comedies ever
reviews.content: "Rushmore" follows up on all the promise shown by Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson's "Bottle Rocket" and then some. Finally, proof that a comedy doesn't have to be a dumbed-down John Hughes knock-off for libinous teens, full of fart and/or private part jokes or in a word....stupid. I was totally engrossed in the world of Rushmore, wanting to know more about the other students, the teachers, Max's history and especially, Herman Blume.  This movie should be nominated for at least Best Original Screenplay and Best Supporting Actor for Bill Murray.  Murray gives one of the most tragi-comic performances ever captured on film.  Jim Carrey should be forced to sit down every day for the next year and watch this movie and see what real "acting" is about.Finally, if there were a Grammy-like best new performer award for the Oscars, Jason Schwartzman would win it hands down.  It amazing to me that a teenager would be capable of the emotional depth of Max Fischer. Thanks Wes and Owen for another

reviews.review_title: People didn't get the movie maybe
reviews.content: I personally liked Rushmore very much, everyone I saw the film with liked it but then there is this big group of people who say it was bad. I think maybe some people didn't get it might be the problem. I guess the previews were making most people think of 'There's Something About Mary 2' only showing certain scenes missing what the story was about. I watched it and I felt sorry for Max, he spent so much time trying to impress people but driving most people insane. But in the end you forgive him. I think the acting was really good, a good performance by newcomer Jason Schwartzman, Bill Murrays at his best.

I rented this movie expecting it to be very funny because of all the critical acclaim and good word of mouth, but I didn't find one thing funny in this entire movie.  If you want to see a good movie about school then go see Election, which is much better.

I understand why people are excited about this movie. It was a very witty and very charming film. However, after all the hype, I expected it would be better than Bottle Rocket and it just isn't. Bottle Rocket is still Wes Anderson's best movie.

reviews.review_title: The Most Original Romantic Comedy In Many A Moon
reviews.content: Although the majority of the public have not responded well to this picture, I can sort of understand why.  The way it's presented is unlike any other film I have seen.  A lot of films have been "done before."  Everything has been rehashed and recycled to the death.  Which is why "Rushmore" is such a blessing.  It doesn't seem to have a pace or a direction.  It doesn't adhere to plot mechanics or oversentimentality.  The film requires patience as well.Those expecting to laugh-out-loud will be truly disappointed. The laughs are more subtle.  As for the performances, Bill Murray is extraordinary. He puts a lot of pathos into his character, and his acting is so subdued that this puts this up there with one of his best performances.  Jason Schwartzman is a revelation.  He makes his character both likable and unlikable in almost the same scenes.  This young man is the real deal.  As are the filmmakers whose last film, "Bottle Rocket", wasn't nearly as good as "Rushmore".I recommend it for those who want something entirely different, unconventional, and unfathomably original.  One of the best films of the 90s.

Rushmore IS an excellent film. The characterizations by the actors (all of them) is superb and it just breaks my heart that Bill Murray was not given his due recognition by the Oscars, but with a movie THIS good, who needs Oscar. Jason Shcwartzman is an incredible find and writer/director Wes Anderson is a rare breed of auteurs who mixes plot and twists with cinematic brilliance(not to mention the excellent soundtrack which, for once, compliments the storyline despite it's odd '60s feel...it captures some kind of innocence unseen in the main character). Definitely one of the year's best film and it should be put up there among recent modern classics. This movie actually left me 'high'...it's too good.

reviews.review_title: A funny little film that's at least worth a matinee
reviews.content: I was pleasantly surprised when I saw this film, the reduced price made it even more worth it.  It starts out a little slow, but quickly becomes hard not to laugh at.  The relationships between Max Flounders and the adult characters are well played and remind us of our own experiences.  My only regrets for the film are that it is so short, only an hour and a half, and much more could have been done with the movie.  Bill Murray is back!

reviews.review_title: A movie that will make you cringe
reviews.content: Max lies, cheats, swindles, and tries to exploit people at every turn.  I didn't like him, didn't want to know him, and left halfway through while Max was insulting strangers at a dinner table.  Maybe it gets better later on, but I doubt it -- the movie suffers from lack of direction even when Max isn't involved, and there's little to recommend it.I'm completely baffled by the positive reviews, and suspect a good deal of them are plants.

The thing I enjoyed most about this movie was that I can honestly say that I have never seen a movie remotely resembling this one.  It is very hard to categorise and I can understand those people used to hyperbole in movies not getting this.  It is very understated with absolutely captivating characters.To categorise broadly, I would say it is in the same quirky, weird characters vein as a Coen brother movie (Fargo, Big Lebowski etc).My vote for best scene is when Bill Murray dives into the pool holding the bottle of scotch and is watched underwater by the kid.  Nothing really happens but infinitely captivating.  Sort of symbolises the rest of the movie.My "if you liked these you will like this guide" is - Any coen brother movie, Six degrees of Separation, As good as it gets.

Rushmore is that kind of movie you just don't see enough of. In fact, it is kind of difficult to put a finger on, but from the opening until the end I had a smile on my face. Without a doubt, Rushmore is in my top 5 favorite flicks of the year. Rushmore was fantastic! I laughed more than I have in a long time. The key is that you have to appreciate dry, subtle, and deadpan humor. I assume you have all seen the film, so you know how great the whole Bill Murray poolside scene is. These kind of sight gags are what separate Rushmore from all the other comedies out there. The acting is superb, and the characters' idiosyncrasies are what make them so lovable. Max Fischer is blessed with a confidence many only dream of, and we become convinced that he could do anything he sets his mind to. The soundtrack is great too, having dug up many long forgotten british invasion groups that fit the film perfectly, like the kinks and 4+2. And Bill Murray deserves recognition for his performance. In short, I think that the majority of the US public has been subjected to low class, base, toilet humor for far too long, as is evident by those who hated this film or don't have the mental capacity to understand humor beyond fart jokes and semen in a woman's hair. Just look, "There's ....Mary" was a box office bonanza, while Rushmore is out of theaters in one month.That should tell you where America is at, and it should scare you too. Us Rushmore lovers need to stick together. For everyone else, it shouldn't be long before Adam Sandler cranks out another piece of garbage to quench your thirst.

reviews.review_title: This has made my list of top ten favorite movies of all time
reviews.content: and if you've seen my list you wouldn't think I was so easily influenced. We're talking Seven Samurai, Raging Bull, Schindler's List, The Empire Strikes Back, Glengarry Glen Ross, Citizen Kane, The Godfather Part II, and others.  Yes, Rushmore is just that good.The so-called teen comedies of the 80s and 90s just didn't work for me - because I never knew those people.  Honestly, does anyone know those people? High schools in film all look like they're from Beverly Hills.   The only realistic teen comedy teen character I can remember (before this film) was Cameron Fry from FBDO.  He at least seemed like a living, breathing teenager, with conflicts and emotions like real people.Then came Max Fischer.  Max Fischer is me.  Max Fischer was High School. Max Fischer was real.I'm not going to go too much into the plot of this one - simply because just when you think it's going to go one way it does an about face and goes somewhere else.  Kind of like real life that way.  I'll just say this - I have never seen the process of "growing up" so accurately portrayed in film like this.Bill Murray was robbed, plain and simple.  That Oscar should have been his. Jason Schwartzman played a very complicated character and pulled it off stunningly.  Olivia Williams was wonderful.Houstonians will delight in the way our city is presented.  The Houston Heights never looked so good.  And in Delmar Stadium (the kite-flying scene) people have flown kites and airplanes for years there on weekends, and it was cool to see it like that.  I learned how to drive a car in Delmar Stadium.Man, I loved this movie.  You will too.

Eccentric student Max Fischer falls in love with one of his teachers, the gorgeous (and recently widowed) ms. Rosemary Cross. When he tells his friend Herman Blume, a bored middleaged buissness-man, about her he realises too late that Herman might be interested in her as well. And the friendship between Max and Herman turns into a war. They never consider the fact that Rosemary might be totally uninterested in both of them.Rushmore is a charming little piece of cinema. It's a comedy that focuses on intelligent humour instead of extreme stupidity. Stupidity can also be funny, but not all the time. The screenplay (written by director Wes Anderson and actor Owen Wilson, who could also be seen in The Haunting) includes some great one-liners and spark-filled dialogue. But it's the cast that impresses mostly with excellent performances from Jason Schwartzman (as Max), Bill Murray (as Herman) and Olivia Williams (as Rosemary) and solid supporting roles from Seymour Cassel, Brian Cox, Mason Gamble, Sara Tanaka and Stephen McCole.Rushmore is a film filled with highlights from director/screenwriter Wes Anderson and the great cast but they're also backed up by an oddball soundtrack and Robert Yeoman's great cinematography.

Like many others I had great expectations - so much critical acclaim this movie has gotten. I am astonished how really weak it is. The main weakness is the plot: undetectable characters (were they supposed to be eccentric?) doing chaotic things, while their actions do not fit characters at all. It seems like authors invented action figures, i.e. masks ("nerd student", "English-accent" teacher, "millionaire", "Asian girl"), and after that they just did not know what to do with them.This movie could be considered quirky or funny only comparing with even more dumb high school films. Stay away from it.

I saw this film because I'd heard it was worth it - but I could never have dreamt how much I was going to enjoy this film.Max Fischer is brought to life before your eyes as a supremely confident, power-hungry, obsessive, abrupt boy whose weaknesses are not immediately apparent. Played with skill and depth by Schwartzman, Max is not, in many ways, a good person, yet he still manages to be the most likeable character of '98.Blume, a wealthy executive, is played with subtle finesse by Murray as depressed, self-loathing and introverted, with a certain deadpan loveability that only Murray could have conveyed.The relationships between the characters are beautifully crafted, and Max's wrath affects Blume in wonderfully subtle ways.Marvelous.

Though it borrows from many movies, altogether there's no movie like RUSHMORE.The film is carried by lead character Max Fischer, who's a terrible student at the Rushmore private boys school, but is a member--often founder--of virtually every club on campus.  Moreover, Fischer is a brilliant playwright, whose talents (he wrote a one-acter about Watergate) in grade two that landed this barber's son a scholarship at this elite academy.Newcomer Jason Schwartzman is wonderful as the madly-driven, irrepressible misfit Max.  Bill Murray plays Mr. Blume, the rich industrialist alumni of Rushmore, becomes unlikely friends (and a father figure) to Max.  This is Murray's best performance to date.  His deadpan portrayal is laced with melancholy that is touching and surprising.  Olivia Williams portrays the young, recently widowed schoolteacher whom Max falls for.  Williams handles this role with sensitivity and grace.  The supporting characters are well-handled, all by child actors.Extra points are awarded to the writers and filmmakers for casting such a racially eclectic film in which Asians, two Scots (though one portrays an American) and blacks share the screen as complex, realistic characters.At times, Max is almost too clever for a boy of 15 and the believability of the film also strains, but sure enough the film bounces back with a fine story twist or touch of comedy to throw it back onto its twisted course.Though RUSHMORE pays hommage to films such as "The Graduate" and "Barry Lyndon" it bears closest resemblance to the black comic classic, "Harold and Maude" in which a young man enters a relationship with a much older woman. In this case, the much-older Murray befriends the 15-year-old Max.  In other words, two misfits find each other.  Also, the soundtrack relies almost exclusively on mid-60s British invasion bands, such as the Kinks, the Who, the Stones and even solo John Lennon, who altogether add an intelligent, hopeful feel to the film along the lines of "Harold and Maude".The highlights of the film are ironically staged plays of "Serpico" and "Heaven and Hell" performed by Rushmore's students.A good film has good supporting performances.  Sara Tanaka, Stephen McCole and Mason Gamble all come through as complex, believable characters.
The writing is witty and never falls into cliche.  Wes Anderson's directing is lively with good use of music and moving camera and a good grip on actors' performances.I didn't know anything about the film when I saw it, but came away championing its originality and verve.

Definitely one of my favorite films.  Quirky humor, the bittersweet quality of the unrequited love of adolescence captured perfectly, a great soundtrack, beautiful cinematography and great performances, what more could you ask for in a movie?Things that run through this movie that I love: - The dogged persistence of Max in his schemes, he is like a force of nature.  Depression stops him briefly but he can't be kept down. and the loyalty of his friendI think there is a lot of symbolism about art and the creative process in this movie.  The cheesy pop culture ripoff plays ("Serpico" and "Heaven and Hell"), while hilarious, I think are symbolic caricatures representing art. Note the injuries suffered by Max in the process of bringing his creations to fruition... "I didn't get hurt too bad" I believe he says at the "Heaven and Hell" cast party after getting his face bloodied yet again...  I like the little tease with the dynamite and the pop gun, where you might think that Max is about to "go postal" at the school instead of using those tools to produce his opus.  This might be considered in poor taste by some after Littleton...There is more than a little symbolism in the clothing worn by Max throughout the movie as he undergoes his metamorphosis, evolving from the ever present Rushmore jacket, through the blue collar outfit and vest when Max is a barber, culminating in the flamboyant green velvet outfit at the Heaven and Hell premiere...In short, a really incredible, beautiful movie... please don't miss this!

I bought this movie in a six dollar bargain bin at my grocery store. Critical raves adorned the cover so I decided to give it a try. What I got in return was the best dark comedy since The Graduate. Rushmore is a dark and powerful story about the folley of youth. It is coated in the smooth comic shell of such films as Harold and Maud or dare I say Pulp Fiction. The acting by Jason Schwartzman is a superb character display. By putting up his awkward front the viewer is allowed to view deeper into his passions, obsessions and motivations. Olivia Williams plays the perfect muse of the affections of Schwartzman and Murray. Murray however somehow manages to shine above the rest in his odd and beautiful comic performances. The other great thing about this film aside from the performances is the music. This is what gave this otherwise serious story it's comic punch. Without it, Schwartzman would have been portrayed more as some obsessive compulsive serial killer than a confused teenager. Classic tunes from the Who and Cat Stevens made this movie work for me. You may not laugh even once during this film but it is sure to give you a big wide smile. This truly is divine comedy. I hope more directors can follow in Wes Anderson's footsteps. All is fare when love is War. Give it a chance.

reviews.review_title: Rushmore is the emergence of a great filmmaker.
reviews.content: Rushmore, Wes Anderson's (Bottle Rocket) sophmore effort is a masterpiece. Anderson puts himself in a category of filmmakers who will set the pace for cinema like the legends of old.  I admit this dark comedy may not be for everyone, but if you enjoyed Bottle Rocket you should love Rushmore. By the way the academy must hate Wes Anderson. Rushmore and The Royal Tenenbaums should have been best picture nominees not to mention Murray and Hackman getting robbed, but who cares I guess you really can't critique art.

Rushmore, directed by Wes Anderson (The Royal Tenenbaums) and starring Bill Murray, is a superb, light-hearted and hilariously funny film about a boy named Max - a 15-year-old student at Rushmore college who excels and enjoys participating in all areas of the school life.Max (Jason Schwartzman) is a bright, well spoken and extremely enthusiastic member of Rushmore who organises and runs a large number of varied co-corricular school activities, ranging from skeet shooting and bee keeping clubs to directing awesome school plays. However Max suffers from a lack of study thanks to his abundance in his extra school activities and faces expulsion from Rushmore if his grades do not improve.Things get out of hand for Max when he falls in love with the Grade 2 English teacher (Olivia Williams) and from here on in Max has to battle his troubles with school and his personal life simultaneously.
Rushmore in my opinion is an absolute brilliant film. Wes Anderson tells this story with style and a unique craftmanship for his work, creating a querky, light-hearted and generally very fun film. It's hard to express the brilliance of Wes Anderson and his unique way of creating such a great film. He's a truly great individual and original film maker.I would rate The Royal Tenenbaums a slightly better film - as it's a more complete film than Rushmore, but equally funny and entertaining.I suggest watching this movie at least twice, as it only gets better the more you watch it!A brilliant film! A must-see. 8/10

reviews.review_title: I wish that I knew what I knew then
reviews.content: Motivation, ah that's the key.  I will admit that I did not see 'Rushmore' upon it initial release in 1998.  I did not follow Bill Murray's career that closely.  However, when December 1998 came and the critics' awards were announced - one name surfaced over and over again from the various groups.. Mr. Murray's.  Curiosity got the best of me and I saw 'Rushmore' on cable over and over again.  (HUGE mistake, Academy on your part, HUGE).  What a performance!  Jason Schwartzman, Olivia Williams, Luke Wilson and Brian Cox just to name a few are perfectly cast as well.The witty dialogue, even the tiniest gesture - a can you top this attitude and the musical score make this film a must see - one viewing is not enough -  you cannot absorb and observe the subtle not overt elements (look for the little things, even the wardrobe of the leads)with just one look.  Did I love this movie ..oo la la ..

This is a delightful film, even if it doesn't know which way it's going sometimes.Max is a sort of converse of Tracy Flick in Election: an overachiever who underachieves.  This is a much warmer film though.While loving the film, I admit to having reservations about the ending: does it imply that Max and Miss Cross might have something going after all?The soundtrack is great, and if watching this doesn't convince you that Bill Murray is one of the best actors we have, I don't know what will.A special word for Stephen McCole as Buchan -- a real Scots actor playing a Scottish part in an American film?  Beam me up, Scotty!

All I can say is that I was completely blown away by this film.  It truly deserves whatever praise is given to it.  I mean, wow.  There is so much subtlety at work here, so much attention to every single nuance of character, so many subplots, that Wes Anderson masterfully and effortlessly juggles around, that upon my first viewing I couldn't believe how much was crammed into this film.I became a Wes Anderson fan after watching The Royal Tenenbaums, and looking back at this old gem, I can tell you how much better it is.  No, it doesn't diminish any of his other films, it is simply filmmaking on a whole new level.  Mr. Anderson is a director who knows his actors in the sense that he can and does make every scene count towards making his audience fall head-over-heels in love with his characters.  And I pity the cold heart that doesn't feel for Max Fischer, or smile when Margaret Yang (played by the beautiful Sara Tanaka) tells him that he treated her like a jerk, in a character turn that shows the audience that Mr. Anderson and his cowriter Owen Wilson aren't making a screenplay for any ol' teen movie here.You could say it's the music that makes "Rushmore".  You could say it's the details.  The way things set-up so well (such as how Max 'recycles' the bike Mr. Bloom thrashed).  Heck, you could even say those funny blink-and-you'll-miss-em moments bring smiles to your face.  Jason Schwartzman pulls off a seemingly effortless performance with just the right amount of honesty, longing and intelligence to make you not only believe his character, but understand why he is who he is.I know it's dangerous to label a movie as an instant classic, but there are no better words to describe how "Rushmore" made me feel. Bravo!

'Rushmore' is the third film of Anderson's that I've seen and the oldest, the others being 'fantastic mr fox' and 'the grand budapest hotel' which are rather different. I went into this not knowing a lot about the plot but that Schwartzman would be playing a student. Schwartzman's character Max is that classic Anderson character that I would have wanted, he is quirky, comical but still has depth. That is found in the other supporting characters too. If you love a character driven story this is ideal for you. It is much different from Anderson's newer films in which they are much more aesthetic driven but there are still the symmetrical shots and 'crime-like' sequences. I would recommend this to any avid film fan who doesn't mind an unusual story about relationships with adults during that coming of age period.

This movie is hilarious. Bill Murray does a fantastic job as a loser. He just doesn't care, and it's really funny. Jason Schwartzman does a spectacular job also as a kid who doesn't know how old to be. The movie is really funky, with all sorts of non-dialogue moments that had me rolling. A very funny movie!

Rushmore is a completely engaging film that is really an arthouse comedy that thankfully made it into wide release.  Bill Murray is a hilarious and pathetic loser who strikes up a competition with another funny and pitiful failure of a 15-yr old, Max Fischer (Jason Schwartzman).  Both of their performances are knee-slappingly comical and at the same time very touching. This movie reminded me of a more upbeat version of Welcome to the Dollhouse.  The scene that really killed me was when Max was drunk and out at dinner with Herman Blume (Murray), Max's love interest Rosemary (Olivia Williams), and Rosemary's friend the doctor.  Max, of course, made a complete ass of himself.  What do you expect from a kid who runs 50 weird extra-curricular clubs at school.  The entire cast was enjoyable, everyone from Dirk (Max's blond sidekick) to the Scottish bully.I believe that Murray is on a real streak now as far as the quality of his performances and the quality of his roles.  Unlike most of his Saturday Night Live comrades, he has done something with his movie career.  Eddie Murphy was good in the 80's but look at the crap he has done recently. Chevy Chase, Dan Aykroyd, and Joe Piscopo aren't even respectable.  Jason Schwartzman is terrific in Rushmore and could possibly have a future in the movie business because un-like many of the young actors of today (i.e. Jennifer Love Hewitt, the cast of Scream), he actually has some acting talent.  Rushmore is a real pleasure and is so far the best movie of 1999.

I went into this movie having loved "Bottle Rocket" and this was even better (I only saw it 5 times in the theater ;) )The cast, script and execution were amazing, and I laughed out loud often, especially when Max joined the Cleveland High School's cheerleaders...

Rushmore was one of the most refreshingly original comedies I've seen in a long time.  'The Truman Show' was breath-taking and original, but it was more of a drama.  This eccentric comedy just hit the right spot with me. 'Rushmore' was perfectly placed right in the middle of a string of crappy movies that were recently released ('She's All That', 'Simply Irresistible') and along with the amazing 'A Simple Plan' got right at the top of my favorite movies of the year (98/99 actually).  Bill Murray was brilliant...but he didn't even try! This movie perfectly portrays the comic genius of Murray.  With good performances by all of the other actors and well directing and writing, 'Rushmore' should have recieved a little more respect from the Academy.  Oh well.

Rushmore is a wonderful, funny film that doesn't rely on potty humor or throwing dogs out windows to make you laugh.Transparently directed and wonderfully acted, this is no John Hughes pubescent fantasy flick, but a mature look at friendship. love and being true to your heart. The main character ( Max Fischer) is one of the most original and eccentric characters in recent cinematic history, surprising us continually throughout the film with his resourcefulness and persistence as well as resilience. Somehow, I ended up respecting Max Fischer even though he is a precocious, impetuous 15 year old kid.Bill Murray plays an uncharacteristic millionaire character with wonderful detachment.I am so happy that Mr. Anderson decided to write real characters, instead of whatever is convenient to move the plot along. Max is real, and deep. We are along for the ride, and also are allowed to think for ourselves.The allegories are presented very nicely. I especially like the fact that Max starts out wanting to build a huge aquarium to woo the unreachable goal of his affections, but in the end as he is flying a kite with his old friend he discovers a love that was there all long. From the depths of  water, to the limitlessness of the sky.Well done Mr. Anderson.

reviews.review_title: The best American comedy, in 30 years!
reviews.content: I saw rushmore a long time ago, like 5 months, but i just can´t keep it out of my mind, its just the balance between drama and hillarious comedy.The only previous work that I can relate Rusmore to, is The Graduate, that kind of very sophisticated humor. Max Ficher, is superbly acted by Jason, and what about Mr Blume, wonderfully played by Murray. A very underated, its unffair, movie that will touch everyone who see it.But, what I can't understad, is that screws like the ultra-proamericans-conquer the world "Saving Private Ryan", recieved tons of nominations and awards, this superior, but smaller movies, are not appreciated, SO DO ME ONE FAVOR PLEASE,RECOMMEND THIS MOVIE TO ANY LIVING PERSON YOU KNOW, PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE...........

reviews.review_title: I would have left the theaters but I was with another couple
reviews.content: of course it turned out they hated it as well. Too bad it's faux pas to talk in theatres. If there had been actors on the stage I would have thrown tomatoes. Jason Shwarzman is/plays the most annoying character ever created. Bill Murray is such an anemic schlub that it's difficult to believe he could win the heart of any woman regardless of how many millions he throws their way. Yuch Yuch Blech. Olivia is attractive, but not enough to sit through two hours of this unrealistic, annoying film. The "O. R. you" line is classic, but it's really the only good line in the film, and everyone already saw it in the previews. Plus think about Shwartzman pulling off that line, and then think about watching that same mean-spirited stupid cowardly humor for 2 straight hours. Makes me wonder if the writer ever got laid.

This is by far my favorite movie in YEARS. It isn't so much the story that defines this movie, but the characters. When Bill Murray and Jason Schwartzman's characters fall for the same woman, we see that adults really are no different than kids when it comes to getting something (or someone) that we want. Bill Murray's best performance EVER! A truly funny and heartwarming look into the life of a well adjusted teenager who DEFINITELY marches to the beat of his own drum. Max Fisher, where were you when I was 15?

If you read the papers, leave your expectations at the door as Rushmore is something less than a comedy.  This heartfelt, though frequently comic and occasionally guffaw-able ramble through the inner workings of a young man's heart plays closer to drama.  Jason Schwartzman is perfect is both look and tone as lovelorn Max, and Bill Murray is, as always, Bill Murray (which is good enough for me).  Olivia Williams is completely charming as the beautiful bereft school teacher for whom Max pines, and Seymour Cassell is perfect casting as Max's content father.  The movie is defiantly offbeat in its viewpoint, teetering between comedy and drama and not fulfilling either genre's cup to the brim.Basic problems for me included: When Max is tossed out of Rushmore his immediate acceptance in public school is unexplored and unconvincing.  His ability to stage a mammoth play in a public high school is not believable and, excuse my density, to what point? That he continues to be Max?  Why a Vietnam story?  And why do Bill Murray's sons have Scottish accents?However, the major flaw in this film is the perpetuation of the idea that a man's (a male's, anyway) attention to a female MUST be reciprocated.  If it is not, the female is at fault.  Max, a charming though fairly overbearing fellow, falls for a teacher, Rosemary, who quite naturally, tells him no, you're too young.  This is the basis of the movie.  However, at the end of the film, Rosemary apologizes to Max for hurting his feelings and he forgives her!  How about Max apologizing for being a pedantic chauvinist in expecting Rosemary to love him just because he loved her?  And how about a callow teenage MALE teaching an - of course -  uncertain adult FEMALE that she isn't effectively dealing with her husband's death?  (Max must have learned this trick by effectively dealing with acne and bad grades.) Unfortunately, RUSHMORE sets Max to grow up and marry himself to his admittedly high-minded pursuits, while we can rest assured that his wife will toil in silence to make him happy and pay homage to his ambition. This is enforced by the fact that Max's new, age-appropriate girlfriend, who initially was smart and forceful, turns out to be a fraud who cheated her results on a science project; Max won't have to worry that he'll be challenged here.Unfortunately, basic male chauvinist tenets are reinforced at the teenage level through RUSHMORE, and the critics rushed forward all too happily to embrace them.  Welcome to America, Max, where women can't fight and die on the front lines but are free to suffer in everyday relationships.  You'll fit right in.

reviews.review_title: Excellent script, but the film didn't pull it all off.
reviews.content: I liked this film a great deal for a few reasons. The script was brilliant. The actors were all solid (Bill Murray in his first good role insome time, Jason Schwartzman in a great star debut). However... The directing didn't cut it. In many scenes the actors didn'tseem to be strongly motivated, which made the performances flat and stilted. The editing gave me problems; it seems as though sceneswere shot with very little coverage, so there weren't manyoptions for the editor (many jump cuts, etc.). It feels like the production didn't have enough time to makethis a really solid effort and had to get what they couldfinished quickly. Unfortunately, this meant that a very goodscript turned into a pretty-good movie.

It's pretty sad when a movie is so bad that Bill Murray isn't even entertaining.  I can usually find something good to say about a movie, like it's acting or cinematography, but this one has me stumped.  Maybe it was trying a little too hard to be different...but it was different in all the ways that distinguish good movies from bad ones.

reviews.review_title: Great movie for the blessed minority of intellectuals.
reviews.content: After seeing that the Royal Tenenbaums was slated ahead of Rushmore on the user rating system here at IMDB, i feel I have to stand up for Wes Anderson's best work (Rushmore and Bottle Rocket). For those of you who loved the Royal Tenenbaums and haven't seen the other Wes Anderson movies, I envy you, because you have quite a show ahead of you! *Especially* with Rushmore, which is slighty better than Bottle Rocket in my opinion.I'll admit, the humor is out there. It is not for all. If you are in love with movies by the Farrelly Brothers, or any teenybopper comedies like American Pie - - STAY AWAY FROM THIS ONE!!! Because you won't get it.I AM SICK AND TIRED of people commenting that they HATED this movie, or that they HATED Bottle Rocket or Tenenbaums, or that they HATED other great movies by great directors (Coens, C.Guest, etc.) So, I'll repeat: IF YOU ARE A COMPLETE IDIOT WHO NEEDS EVERYTHING SPOON-FED - - just simply STAY AWAY! You don't get it, and you never will. The easiest solution to your problem is to just put your leash back on get back in your line - - and STAY AWAY FROM ME!!!!hehehe, just had to get that off my chest. .. .anyway, rushmore is a great movie if you enjoy something a little different... "Take dead aim on the rich kids. Get them in the crosshairs, and take them down"

Wes Anderson shows his inner toxicity. The lead character, Max Fischer, is unbearably emotionally abusive and main goal throughout the movie is to escape the friend zone that his teacher, Rosemary Cross, has put him in. The female lead is degraded to a token whose only positive experiences in the movie are designed by men trying to get into her pants. "No" is never accepted as an answer and her good heart is taken advantage of by the minute. As a person with a bit of empathy this hurts to watch and distracts from the creativity that was poured into this movie.

With films this fine, I really shouldn't have to say anything more than this; buy it, cherish it, and spread the word!Hot from the critical acclaim of Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson's first collaboration, Bottle Rocket, Rushmore was even more widely appreciated than it's predecessor. With a bigger star cast (Bill Murray, Jason Schwartzman, Olivia Williams, Brian Cox), all of which fire on all cannons in this wonderful comedy about the unlikely love triangle which forms between three unlikely friends.On a personal note, I really have to say that this kind of writing and directing talent does not come along often, and when it does, it makes me remember why I love cinema so much in the first place...I cannot praise this film enough! Perfection!

When I first saw Rushmore, I was stunned. Wes Anderson crafted superb characters and placed them into a plot that was not only darkly humorous, but also wrenchingly dramatic. Max Fischer (played brilliantly by Jason Schwartzman) is crafty, yet deeply flawed enough to be entertaining. And Bill Muarry's performance is fantastic. It's certainly one of the best independent films ever made, if not, one of the best films ever made.

reviews.review_title: I can't for the life of me see what people like about this film!
reviews.content: Story: Boring Plot: Goes nowhere, slowly. Characters: Didn't like a single one. What Went Wrong: Just about everything. I wanted to like this movie based on what I'd heard from friends who loved it, but it just never went anywhere. It started bad, and just kept getting worse. I wanted to stop the DVD many times, but based on the great reviews that I had heard, I somehow convinced myself that it was going to get better at any moment. Boy, was I wrong about that!Summary: I'm sad because I will never get back these 93 minutes of my life. Quite honestly, I was shocked to find out that this movie was only 93 minutes, because it felt more like 180 minutes. This is one of the five worst movies that I've ever seen.

I think the first time I saw this movie, back in 1999, I didn't get the point and just considered a really cool teenage movie. Wrong! This is my advice to you, watch it over and over again, attention to the small details around the scenes, the furniture, the clothes, the children. I don't need to talk about all the great roles, the amazing soundtrack and the care of Wes Anderson to make everything seem to be so beautiful, funny, touching and perfect. This peace of art became easily my favorite movie. Thanks, Mr. Anderson.

reviews.review_title: A touching journey of love, hate and self discovery
reviews.content: Rushmore is directed by Wes Anderson and stars his frequent collaborators Jason Schwartzman and Bill Murray. Despite it only being Anderson's second feature, it still remains one of his best and the film which opened the eyes of the world to his work. The story follows a student named Max Fisher (played by Schwartzman) on a journey of love, hate and self discovery.This film is a true testament of the strengths we have come to expect from Anderson as a director and a writer. It has clever dialogue, complex and well written characters, great music and wonderful cinematography. In addition to this, Anderson creates a story so filled with dark humor and deep emotion it is impossible to look away.Rushmore is perhaps the most realistic coming of age depiction ever put on screen and there is a few reasons why. The film deals largely with the question of acceptance and what it means to belong somewhere. When we meet Max, it is clear that he belongs at his school Rushmore, this is until he falls in love with a school teacher named Rosemary and she becomes his new sense of belonging. Later in the film when he gets kicked out of school and repelled by Rosemary we therefore learn that behind Max's confident exterior is a real feeling of disconnection and that forces him on a coming of age journey.Max and many other characters in this movie can seem too quirky and weird at first glance, but it's their unfiltered personas that makes them real. As viewers, some of the decisions the characters make fills us with love for them, while others fills us with hate. However, we learn to accept and even like them all, despite their many flaws. This is when one realises that the story brings us on a similar journey as Max's and by the end of it we can just like him, accept all sides of ourselves and recognise that it's okay to be whoever we are, as long as we are open for change. In many ways, the story brings its own concept to us, we feel like we belong in this crooked world, mainly because of how we can find something relatable in every single character in this film. Whether it's Max's dark humor, self consciousness and passion or Herman Blume's feeling of regret, self hatred and dissatisfaction.This is a beautiful film about wounded hearts latching on to each other, whether your heart is wounded or not, I recommend that you latch on to this story and keep it close. What Anderson created with this film is the kind of magic you rarely see, much less experience.

Wes Anderson's 2nd feature film Rushmore is possibly one of the strangest coming-of-age films ever made. It involves blackmail, murder attempts, illegal-aquarium-building, and bee keeping, all within a 93 minute run time. That being said, it is also one of the funniest. Rushmore tells the story of a precocious 15 year old named Max Fischer attending a spiffy private school called Rushmore, and his increasingly bizarre attempts to woo a kindergarten teacher who he crushes on. Jason Shwartsman is brilliant in the lead role, imbuing a seemingly irredeemable character with a quirky charm. This film also features a hilariously deadpan performance from Bill Murray.Rushmore is Wes Anderson's first film to showcase his signature style, though it is not as well-defined as in his later works. The film is the earliest example of his stark camera movements, symmetrical framing, and deadpan dialogue. As such, it is perhaps the easiest film in which to spot Wes Anderson's influences, most notably Hal Ashby's quirky classic Harold and Maude. These elements give the film a unique charm, and have allowed it to endure as a cult classic. The one issue I have with this movie is that it perhaps too easily forgives the flaws of its protagonist, who at one point forcibly tries to kiss another character. However, this can be overlooked as the film's primary theme is forgiveness, and the protagonist undergoes a large amount of character growth. At its heart, Rushmore is a character study and a coming of age story, and is full of quirky charm, humor, and heart.

This was one of the funniest movies I've seen in a long time.  Bill Murray deserved an Oscar nomination for this movie.  Just an incredibly original movie.  I can't see how it didn't do better at the box office.  Definitely a must see.

This is one of those rare films that not only had me frequently laughing out loud, but also continuously smiling. This is mostly attributable to the depth of the characters, as well as the skillful performances of Bill Murray and Jason Schwartzman. It was refreshing to see character portraits that were not drawn as simplistic this-is-the-good-guy, this-is-the-bad-guy caricatures. Max is not a hero, but we root for him. His sometimes-despicable actions make us cringe, and yet one can only laugh as he and Murray's Blume, after their falling-out, resort to the dirty revenge tactics typical of passionate, spurned lovers. They, like most real people (as opposed to the cardboard cut-outs depicted in the vast majority of movies), are neither villains nor saviors, just people with good moments and bad moments.  What makes them worthy of watching, though, is their spark, their desire to achieve extraordinary results from their ordinary lives. Max is a poor academic student who nonetheless craves knowledge, an idealist who disguises his introversion by being outgoing.  At his worst, he is a petty, whining brat; At his best, he strives to bring out the best in others.Bill Murray is at his finest, and left me wishing he had more screen time. He is aware of the value of an actor's eyes, with a subtly averted gaze or barely-perceptible dawning registering much more than "acting" ever could.I imagine those who had an intense aversion to this picture (as evidenced by the postings here) had best go back to renting Armageddon for their cinematic stimulation. Obviously, the unconventional style of Rushmore left them addled and angrily confused, and the familiar blockbuster dose of a noisy, destruction-and-debris-filled ending (followed twenty minutes later by another noisy, destruction-and-debris-filled ending) will allay their fears that Hollywood is no longer going to produce mind-numbing feature-length music video crap anymore. It's okay, anonymous, don't weep--another by-the-numbers spectacular with a trite ballad by Aerosmith with be along any Friday soon, I guarantee it.

This movie is possibly the most new and original movie I've seen in years. The plot is great and it is wonderfully constructed. And the Music, oh the music, the songs fit each scene perfectly and the score is so light and jumpy. The acting in it is wonderful and they pull you into believing they're real people and you feel like you know them. I love it and give it a 10.

while the lot of these negative reviews bewilder me (too loud?), i suppose i am not surprised. Rushmore, while a brilliant film, is not a conventional one, and while i'd love for it to succeed, i have a sneaking suspicion that word of mouth from the likes of these close minded people will ruin it's chances of being a huge success (but then again, does that even matter?). it seems nowadays if you're not a You've Got Mail or a Something About Mary, you don't even have a chance for big success in the comedy field. It's a shame that such an intelligent, fresh coming of age film such as this will probably go unnoticed for the most part. The acting was great. a superb debut from Jason Schwartzman, a "The Postman" forgiving performance by Olivia Williams, and of course, there is Bill. I have to say, i really DO wish, and think he deserved an Academy Award nomination. Do Ed Harris and Robert Duvall REALLY deserve that? another bright note was that aside from the principal cast members, i found the whole supporting cast to be above-pleasing as well, which is usually rare in films like these. Anyway, add in the fantastic direction and scribe from our "Bottle Rocket" team Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson, and a FABULOUS British wave soundtrack and you've got one beautiful film.

Rushmore is the best movie of that long ago decade known as the 1990s. I love the overall style of this movie, a style that has since become the standard for Wes Anderson movies.The visual style is brilliant: deliberate tracking shots, centered wide angle shots. The musical style: classic pop/rock music from the 1960s and 1970s. The acting style: quirky and understated.I have watched Rushmore many times and am never bored. Rushmore is like its main characters, Max Fisher and Herman Blume, in that it is equal parts genius, melancholy, lonely, and, ultimately, sweet.Rushmore is highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: Main characters that smoke are a big turn off
reviews.content: The first three out of four scenes for the main female character showed her smoking a cigarette.  I don't mind that to much, but the two main male characters who were attracted to this person were non-smokers.  The movie was not billed as being the type to have a smoking type of main character. I can not believe in a plot where two normal people are fighting over a person that is doing a very unattracting act.

Rushmore is a perfect film. I can find no faults and have no criticisms. I was highly disspointed when it garnered no Oscar nominations - not that it would ever win mind you, but I feel it at least deserved the recognition. It is extremly smart, well acted, and incredibly well written. My only question is what else is in the 100 minute long Canadian cut that is listed in IMDB. I need more. Also, the soundtrack by Mark Mothersbaugh (DEVO) is perfection.

reviews.review_title: Modern-day masterpiece (often over-used, but not in this case)
reviews.content: I can't say enough good things about this film. I came into the theater with pretty high expectations after being a big fan of "Bottle Rocket", and then Wes Anderson goes and exceeds those expectations. Everybody I've talked to said the same thing, "I wanted to see this movie again immediately after it was over." Great dialogue, characters, cinematography, you name it. Anybody who can't relate to these very human and realistic characters was probably the local football jock or head cheerleader. Anybody who couldn't follow this plot probably thinks Godzilla and Titanic are great films. This film said a great deal without spelling it out for the lowest common denominator. The Max Fischers of the world shall take over!

Following in the same odd-ball vein as "Raising Arizona" and "Fargo," "Rushmore" focuses on Max Fisher, a private school genius, who feels the rules simply don't apply to him, in academics, in administration, and--particularly in this film--in romance. He defies every convention and authority with varying degrees of success. Max finds a hero in Bill Murray's Mr. Blume character who, likewise, has found a certain degree of success by violating social standards and going against the odds.Despite most reviews, this is far from Murray's best. However, he does a fine job with a strange character and you understand his plight, while not really identifying with it. He has worked his way to the top, and in the process realized this wasn't what he was bargaining for. He's in a loveless marriage, raising neanderthal sons, and entertaining and associating with people he despises. In Max he finds the boy without convention, with unabashed ambition, flawless manipulation of those around him, and boundless zeal and ingenuity to bypass every form of authority around him.This movie is unadulterated farce. Perhaps the funniest scenes in the movie come as 10-15 year olds play CIA agents, Vietnam soldiers, and members of the mafia in Max Fisher original plays. Juxtaposing these images with what children usually play in third or fourth grade plays (a carrot, a tooth, a tree, Ebeneezer Scrooge...), you understand this movie is not merely to be taken at face value but is probably more allegorical. While probably not as directly symbolic as, say, "Grand Canyon," it definitely makes a comment about ambition and convention.Overall, this movie is not to be taken seriously. This is far from an Adam Sandler/Jim Carrey mindless comedy with plenty of sewer humor and sight gags. Unfortunately the story does have several (unnecessary) sexual overtones which detract from the movie's overall messages (although I'm sure many would argue with that). In the end, it's about ambition, disillusionment, convention and finding your place in the world. If those are themes you can identify with, Rushmore is worth your time.

reviews.review_title: Off-beat and extremely original script, Bill Murray's performance is unbelievable.
reviews.content: The script and plot are as engaging as they are twisted.  Murray is the best as I have ever seen him-it's a perfect role for him.  The seventies psychedelic soundtrack is fresh.  The character of Max is one of the most complex roles and is capable of carrying the film alone.

reviews.review_title: Definitely the funniest movie of the year
reviews.content: 'Rushmore' was a rare treat of a film that was different without blatantly trying.  It was cool and original without being trendy.  It was hilariously funny without being gimmicky.  It had great, strong characters who were all so believable.  It also was a good story without a plot that punched you in the face, but rather hid behind the tree like Bill Murray in the memorable finger-painting scene.  Jason Schwartzman will be a star, and hopefully some day Bill Murray will get proper recognition for being one of the funniest men in the world. 'Rushmore' may not be for everybody, but if you don't like it the first time you see it, go see it again.  Movies like this don't come out too often, don't under-appreciate this one.

One of the most quirky, wonderful films I´ve ever seen, "Rushmore" rings absolutely true. When describing the film to my friends (most of whom hadn´t even heard about it - it didn´t open in theaters in Denmark) I´ve mentioned the superb acting, the brilliant, sparkling dialogue, the wonderful soundtrack, the (many) memorable scenes. But - to me, at least -  the real charm of the film is hard to put into words. So I guess I´ll just leave it at that.I you haven´t seen "Rushmore" yet, go do so. If you´re anything like me, it´ll get you right in the heart.

reviews.review_title: Surreal, oddly touching, and painfully amusing
reviews.content: First, I need to correct two things that were said in previous comments:1.  The main character is not named Rushmore, Rushmore is the school.  The main character is Max Fisher.2.  One of the characters that was attracted to Miss Cross was already a smoker (Bill Murray's character), and the other one soon became a smoker for her, just as he saved Latin classes (which, by the way, he got cancelled) and tried to build her an aquarium.This movie was a surprise.  I'm not at all shocked that so many people have expressed their dislike for it, as you can feel nearly everything the characters are going through, and many people just aren't ready for that kind of realism.  It's not a comedy (although there are some moments that made me laugh out loud), it's not a drama, it's not anything, other than maybe a character study, and an explanation of how one young man learns to cope with everything.If you can handle it, this is a fantastic movie.

Over the last 5-6 months ive been watching films that have disappointed me and left a sort of emptiness inside me. Then along came Rushmore and yes, that emptiness soon went. In fact Rushmore filled the hole (so to speak) so well that i really cant imagine anything beating it. Its not just the perfect directorial technique or the once in a career script writers life script that does it. So many people on here have put the film down in so many different ways and of course thats fine. What these people have to ask is what did they expect from this film? Its everything anyone who wanted to be entertained/inspired could ask for. The intelligent yet charmingly vulnerable Max, the seemingly stone cold Mr blume who turns out to be completely the opposite, its perfect. I cant say anything else that will make you want to watch this but i can say this, once in a while films come along that are truly original, these films live in the memory for a long time and question the ideology of..life, its true and i might sound strange for saying it but those of you reading this and have seen the film and either enjoyed it/hated it might want to ask yourselves this question...what is the secret?Who knows?

reviews.review_title: A creative, quirky, humorous and well written film.
reviews.content: Max Fisher (Jason Schwartzman) is a character you believe is a bit demented but through the course of the film you end up appreciating his style. I believe we all know some form of "Max Fisher" in high school... not an academic achiever but a mover/shaker. The type that ends up on his feet and does some remarkable things. That is the case in this film. He operates at a level far beyond his years, no wonder he desires an older woman and is close friends with a late 40-ish millionaire.I really liked this film on so many levels :Bill Murray's deadpan looksthe soundtrack... so appropriate during certain scenesthe whole supporting cast (especially Max's sidekick Kirk)scene sequencingthe character's attireOverall, a good quality film by Wes Anderson.

reviews.review_title: b e a u t i f u l: the ultimate feel-good movie
reviews.content: This movie was absolutely beautiful. The script was hilarious, the characters were unique, the score was infectious and the direction was sparkling youthful ingenuity.I love this movie so much because it has to be the only movie (or one of the rare,rare movies) that made me feel this great after I saw it.  It is the ultimate feel-good movie because it has ZERO amount of cheese and just the right dollop of..umm "feel-goodness" for lack of a better term.Max Fischer is the best character I've seen on screen.  What fascinates me about him is that technically he is so unreal--I don't know anyone and I can't imagine anyone being close to a Max Fischer--and yet in the movie he is made real, he is made incarnate as a believable human being--one with passions, faults, quirks, mannerisms, etc.In my opinion the movie was really about the maturing of Max Fischer. Max Fischer was a guy boy could--and did--do anything. From his enrollment in Rushmore at age seven he was an overachieving freak, an oversuccessful success story.  And in that sense, he was spoiled. Then he falls in love with Miss Cross and for the first time ever he has a goal he cannot achieve. By the end of the movie he has grown up because he lets this goal go; this shows in the resolution between him and Cross and Herman (Murray).There were so many beautiful parts in this movie: Max's speech in his new public school (he was a fish out of water, it was hilarious); the part when Max introduces Herman to his dad, a barber and *not* a brain surgeon; Max's first meeting with Miss Cross.. Every scene in this movie is perfect; the fact that the movie doesn't drag is a major plus.All in all, I loved this movie. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys a funny, feel-good movie.by the way, can someone please give me another word for "feel-good"?!?!

I have seen this movie probably 10 times, and everytime I watch it, I love it.  For those who don't think it's funny, well, they really don't get it. It's not Adam Sandler, nor is it American Pie.  The humour relies on quirkiness, irony, and just the plain bizarre.  None of it is over the top, and that's why it's so great.  The fact that the humour isn't blatent yet still incredibly funny makes a great comedy.  Bill Murray is incredibly funny, doing the same shtick he does in The Man Who Knew Too Little (a pretty good film) and Charlie's Angels (God Awful crap).  Olivia Williams is incredibly beautiful, and Jason Schwartzman makes the film.  He's uncanny wit and his odd looks make him perfect for the role of Max.  Besides Stanley Kubrick's Dr. Strangelove (which also doesn't use the in your face bodily fluids/functions humour, yet is funny), Rushmore is my favorite movie. This is a must see for anyone who wants to laugh while still watching a great and meaningful movie.

Wes Anderson is one of my all-time favorite directors and he only has two films.  Rushmore is about freedom.  The freedom to be yourself, to be unselfconscious, to let your mind roam and behave any way you want.  I feel jealous at how passionate and free Max (the lead) is.    Anderson's films celebrate the unusual among us, and not in that lame Hollywood way with drivel like Forest Gump.  The lead in the movie is a bizarre character and he is fascinating and endearing for it.  The thing I love best about Max is that he is so full of life and passion.Anderson is also a fantastic director.  The movie was shot beautifully (reminiscent of the style of "The Graduate") and there was (as with Bottle Rocket) a quirky yet powerfully emotional soundtrack.  Nothing about Rushmore is conventional yet--and this is important--it never tries to shock you in a cheap Hollywood way with violence, sex, or some special effects crap.  This to me is the ultimate in film making (and any art for that matter)--it is at once entertaining, intelligent, unique, emotional, and thought provoking.  Rushmore is so rich with so many things and is well balanced between all of them.  A TEN.

On the artsy side, I'm not a huge Bill Murray fan, and if you're not either: don't be scared.  The movie is great, the star is the kid, the story is phenomenal, the subtle (and not so subtle) references to other movies are hilarious, the commentary on public schools it biting, the view of childhood is insightful and witty.  You liked "Saving Grace" and "The Big Lebowski" you'll like this.

This is an amazing film. I originally watched this several years back. I was quite a bit younger then but still appreciated the film. However, I just re-watched this movie and felt compelled to say how simply amazing it was. I don't know how to describe it, but I just related to this movie so well. It's just like the great novels you read in high school. You hate them and find them pointless (In my case) at the time. But, fast-forward 4-5 years and suddenly it all makes sense. I still don't like Tenanbums as much, but perhaps that just because of bad experiences. I will have to give it a re-watch too. This review doesn't really do the movie justice, nor does it really explain anything at all. In fact, all I wanted to say was that I liked this movie. It is also worth noting that the music is so perfect for this movie!

I thought that this film was one of the best I have seen in quite some time. How refreshing it was to go the picture theatre and not have over-the-top special effects try to quite literally blow you off your seat. A simple story, no violence and an inspirational finale. Im not  totally against violence or special effects in films yet it was good to see real characters effectively  portray the ideals of an excellently written tale. I wont explain the film, I'll just let you discover that for yourself.

Rushmore is pure fiction, unbelievable, and unrelateable yet Wes Anderson crafts it perfectly. A plot which contains something that would never happen yet during the viewing of the film you fall into it. Because it was such a different style of comedy and judging it is his 3rd film, i loved it and everyone i forced to see it loved it as well. Although the unattractive title made give the viewer a bias opinion of the film but like they say it is the contents of the book that matter not the cover. I really cant say much of this film due to the limited knowledge of the director and his work but I love and I am sure you will too.

reviews.review_title: Subtle brand of humor makes Rushmore unique
reviews.content: Rushmore stands out as a comedy because it is not just a string of jokes, but more than a sum of it's parts. You could not expect to tune in half-way through and still understand the humor, or the drama. You could not turn off your brain (a prerequisite to enjoy most comedies in theaters these days) and still enjoy the film. Wes Anderson's direction is fresh and, along with the soundtrack, makes the movie very lighthearted and fun. I can't name another movie to liken it to, besides it's successor, The Royal Tenenbaums.

Max (Schwartzman) is king or extra-curricular activities but his school work is suffering. Enter the elementary school teacher that he falls in love with, and throw the fact that Max's industrialist friend is after her too into the mix, and you get a whole lot of complications. It's a great funny romantic awkward movie. That makes you keep interest the whole time because you don't know what will happen next. It's a movie for all ages. Max fisher is an awkward adventurous confident kid who does everything he can to get the second grade teacher to like him back. I recommend this movie to a friend.
Michael Vino

reviews.review_title: I guess I just don't get it.
reviews.content: While this movie certainly had its moments, over all it just didn't work for me.  The characters didn't seem self consistent, and I couldn't figure out why they were behaving the way they were most of the time.  Add in the sometimes jerky editing and lukewarm acting and you get a final product that is less than satisfying.

I sneaked into this film back when it was still in the movie theater because i am of the opinion that if i have to pay $9 to get into the place, I should be able to see at least 2 movies.  Anyway, I started snorting out little surprised laughs in the first few minutes and ended up leaving the theater with a smile planted on my face that lasted for hours afterwards.  The scene where Bill Murrary gives the teacher a letter from Max and then sprints away and the dance at the end are two of my favorite scenes from any movie. Can't wait for the next wes anderson movie.

This movie was so endearingly offbeat and dry that I had to love it.  From the team that created Bottle Rocket comes another highly original story. There is no high principle or morals to discuss over coffee here, but rather the ingenuity of putting together eccentric characters.  I'm going to call this a feel good movie because the filmakers obviously have an optimism about being a dreamer and following the path that you make for yourself.  I laughed OK.

reviews.review_title: one of the most under-rated movies......
reviews.content: In viewing "Rushmore" for a second time, I picked up a lot of the little things in the movie that make it so great.  The pool scene with the Bill Murray character is one of the best directed scenes in the movie. You can feel his depression.  But the movie is so much more.  Listen to the way the characters talk to each other, react to each other, listen to each other. Its the way real people act, and unfortunately it happens all too little in movies. Also note the last scene (the dance) and how the director (Anderson)has assembled every supporting character there.  It truly is a smart film.

A movie that makes you realize what dull predictable formula pap so many are nowadays.  Rushmore will keep you guessing what the fate of these likeable (!) human (!) characters will turn out to be.  It is truly hilarious without making the characters seem like marionettes playing out gags.And Bill Murray is the king of 'em all, y'all.

I really didn't like this movie. It was weird and really...I don't know just weird.  And HELLO it was not a comedy, it was not funny, ok there were a few take-offs on other movies but they weren't funny.  To me this movie was about how some brat with an inflated ego who crashes and becomes a self hating depressed dilinquent over his little crush on a teacher.  My over all opinion of it was that it was terrible and anyone looking for a comedy should not see it.  Some people might like it if they are maybe quite, well really off beat and/or artsy and looking for a pathetic, but harsh, drama.

reviews.review_title: slapstick isn't the only way to achieve laughter
reviews.content: for all you chris farley and adam sandler fans, wait for their next lemon-uva-movie, and let the intelligent people have the good seats at rushmore.   This movie does not cater to the half-minded, myopic film goer-s who just wanna sit and eat popcorn.  This movie must be thought about. Every little comment adds character and reality to the script, and Wes doesn't feel like he should have to show you when to laugh, those who pay attention and focus will fall in love with this movie.  Those who wait for scenes of bodyparts in zippers and waterboys tackling school teachers will be disappointed; i counted only one slapstick joke in the entire movie.  For those who judge it based on the color of trees during different seasons, be sure to note that the entire movie was shot in houston, and i only noticed one shot with any kind of temperate plant life, so Wes completely blew me away with his sets--i know, i'm trying to make tropical central florida look like connecticut--Jason S. is completely comfortable as a character, among acting virtuosos Bill M. and Olivia W.  It was also great to see some of the people from Bottle Rocket, who were just as good in this movie--Kumar is the best!!!--The thing that makes this movie so great is that the writers, Wes A. and Owen W. didnt seem to change their character and style to create this movie, and the entire film gives the air of "i don't care if no one likes this, this is the way we do movies"   Almost as if it was accepting the fact that some would love it, and others would hate it, unlike other films today [cough 8mm cough] and don't even tell me this thing didn't have style...anyone would be hard pressed to match this style, visually or technically. BRAVO!

About 30 minutes into this film, I knew I was in.  Anderson had me in the grip of a masterpiece in comic clothing.In a deluge of adolesco-centric hormone-drenched films, *Rushmore* stands on mythic ground.  Young Max (Jason Schwartzman), the "Fischer" King, is Arthur, full of dreams and schemes for the glory of his beloved Rushmore Academy/Camelot.  A world-weary alum/knight, Herman Blume/Lancelot (Bill Murray), offers friendship and betrayal on a monumental (literally) scale. For they both love the fair (and English) Miss Rosemary Cross/Guinevere, even as they love Rushmore/Camelot.And don't think that only the central plot structure of Arthur-Lancelot-Guinevere is present.  Indeed, there is a delightful and deep purity in Dirk/Sir Galahad.  The elusive Holy Grail may be harder to nail down--I think it's actually what motivates young Max to start all of his numerous escapades.  Or is it in fact Max's more noble goal--like Arthur--to provide charismatic leadership to his disaffected, prefabricated, ready-for-the-corporate-mill school chums?  Not unlike what Arthur and his romantic chivalry was to Middle Age England...Wes Anderson may just be our times' Tennyson, with his *Rushmore* a wonderful parallel to *Idylls of the King.*Add to this incredible retelling of a slightly mad young Man's kingly aspirations solid writing, brilliant camera work, inspired acting, outstanding use of slow-motion, and hauntingly perfect soundtrack, and you've got the makings of a true masterpiece.Thanks for bringing this reviewer out of a dreck-induced funk! Kudos to all!

Rushmore is one of those great, perfect movies that come along so rarely. ..and are wasted on about 80% of the people that see them. What I mean is, that percentage of people will call Rushmore slow, unamusing, and crass. The easiest (and maybe strangest) way to describe it is that it takes PATIENCE to watch. It suits those who can sit and watch a movie for what it is, as opposed to what it isn't. Rushmore is a brilliantly subtle masterpiece by director Wes Anderson. The emotional depth and fantastic script are rarities in an industry of explosions and action heroes.

It's been over 24 hours since I've seen Rushmore and I'm still smiling.  I laughed until I cried, but mostly I could not wipe the smile off my face. It was the most enjoyable film experience I can remember having.The performances of Bill Murray and especially Jason Schwartzman (he is not getting his due!) were perfect and I don't even believe in perfection.  I ask anybody who criticized their performances how they would do it?  These guys did not miss a single beat.This is writing.  This is acting.   This is a great movie.

reviews.review_title: Unique nerd flick with wit and soul
reviews.content: Before I watched this film I caught a few previews showing some absolutely horrendous crap being pumped out by the major US studios...then this flick came along and filled me with awe at how good and unique "Rushmore" is. Somewhat indescribable (nerd flick with wit and soul?), the soundtrack, the script and most resonating the performances of Bill Murray, Jason Schwartzman as Max and Olivia Williams mark this as a remarkable film. For anyone who's been in love and been rejected, for anyone wanting to belong and be unique, for anyone with dreams and frustrations, this is a must-see.

If you've ever felt unrequited love, this movie is for you.  A wonderfully comic, yet touching, love tale that satisfies both the intellect as well as the heart.  Bill Murray is his best as the disappointed paramour who's life, despite great financial riches, is bitter and empty.  Jason Swartzman played the role of Max Fisher perfectly, capturing both the adolescent love and Holden Caulfied-like angst of his character.This film should be in everyone's collection and certainly on the Top 250 list.

reviews.review_title: Former Girl Scout gives "Rushmore" two thumbs up and a merit badge
reviews.content: Rushmore doesn't have Gwyneth Paltrow. It doesn't have Ben Affleck. It doesn't have meteors, a high intensity street shoot-out or any special effects to speak of. It does have one thing that plenty of recent movies don't seem to have: good actors, good acting and a decent story.Rushmore is a posh boy's academy where our hero, Max Fischer [newcomer Jason Schwartzman] gets an extensive education in everything except academics. I suppose the foundation of the story is familiar: boy meets girl, boy falls for girl.... The boy in this story is Max, who spends so much of his time founding and participating in extracurricular clubs for every and all hobbies [such as beekeeping, fencing, chess, Model UN] that he neglects his studies and is in danger of failing out of his beloved Rushmore. The girl is a first grade teacher at Rushmore, Rosemary Cross, played by Olivia Williams who you might remember from "The Postman." Then again, you might not. The best friend-cum-traitor is Herman Blume, a captain of industry trapped in an unhappy marriage, smartly played by Bill Murray. The movie centers around one basic maxim that is sweet, poignant and genius when uttered by the braced teeth and bespeckled Max: "The key to life is finding something you love to do and doing it for the rest of your life."I won't ruin the end by telling you which, if any, of the characters fulfill this maxim, just that Anderson and Wilson don't patronize us by handing us a neatly wrapped happy ending. It's relatively certain that the future is hopeful and happy for our players, but the characters are complex enough that we can rest assured they face normal lives full of joy, sadness, failures and contentments, too.Possibly the best element of Rushmore is that the three main characters all have some undesirable personality traits that allow them to be less static. The characters aren't cut and dry, all bad or all good. They have depth and can be equal parts caring and cruel. Save some over zealous eyebrows and some growing up, there is virtually nothing unlikable about Max Fischer. He's the kind of character that approaches each task in his life, including his life as a whole project, with genuine earnestness. Miss Cross is there to remind us that dignity, reservation, gentleness and kindness are beautiful.
